questions.text: Which of the following is not a possible cause of the salt and pepper appearance of the fundus in a patient?
Which of the following is not seen in very severe NPDR?
questions.explanation:
Severity

Definition

Very mild nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy

Microaneurysms only

Mild nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy

Microaneurysms plus hard exudates, cotton-wool spots, and/or mild retinal hemorrhages

Moderate nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy

Microaneurysms plus mild intraretinal microvascular abnormalities or moderate retinal hemorrhages

Severe nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy

Any one of the following (4-2-1 Rule)

  • Severe retinal hemorrhages in four quadrants
  • Venous beading in at least two
  • Moderately severe intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA) in at least one quadrant

Very severe nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy

Any two of the following (4-2-1 Rule)

  • Severe retinal hemorrhages in four quadrants (Option C ruled out)
  • Venous beading in at least two (Option A ruled out)
  • Moderately severe intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA) in at least one quadrant (Option D ruled out)

Early NPDR or Background Diabetic Retinopathy

Severe NPDR or Preproliferative Diabetic Retinopathy
  • Affects small retinal vessels.
  • Earliest sign: Microaneurysm
    • Fluorescein angiography (FA): Tiny hyperfluorescent dots.
  • Retinal hemorrhages: Both deep, i.e., in the inner nuclear or outer plexiform layer (dot and blot hemorrhage) and superficial, i.e., in nerve fiber layer (splinter or flame-shaped) hemorrhages
  • Hard exudates:
    • White or yellow waxy patches with well-defined margins, often at the posterior pole, in the outer plexiform layer.
    • FA: Hypofluorescence with dense exudates.
  • Edema is not marked.
  • Increased inner retinal hypoxia: Leads to multiple retinal hemorrhages, cotton-wool spots, venous beading, vascular loops, intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMAs), and large areas of capillary nonperfusion.
  • Cotton-Wool Spots:
    • Also called soft exudates or nerve fiber infarcts.
    • Result from ischemia, not exudation.
    • Caused by obstruction of axoplasmic flow, leading to swelling and a white, fluffy appearance.
    • FA: Focal hypofluorescence due to local ischemia.
  • Venous Beading:
    • Indicates sluggish retinal circulation.
    • Typically adjacent to large areas of capillary nonperfusion. (Option D)
  • Intraretinal Microvascular Abnormalities (IRMA):
    • Dilated capillaries act as collateral channels.
    • Bypass capillary bed and is often seen adjacent to capillary nonperfusion.
    • FA: Focal hypofluorescence

questions.text: The image below displays the findings of a fundoscopy. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - CRAO

questions.text: In a three-year-old boy, his parents have noticed a progressive decline in coordination over the last six months. During a physical examination, a growth resembling a cauliflower is observed in the left eye, along with leukocoria and the absence of a red reflex. Microscopic analysis of the sample reveals the presence of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes. Which gene is associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Rb gene

Histopathology
  • Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes (highly specific)- These are composed of an ‘empty’ lumen surrounded by columnar cells
  • Homer-Wright rosettes - These are pseudo-rosettes and consist of cells surrounding a central lumen made up of their processes
  • Undifferentiated tumor cells
  • Areas of necrosis and calcification

Clinical Presentation
  • Leukocoria (60%)
  • Strabismus (20%)
  • Painful red eye (7%)
  • Poor vision (5%)
  • Asymptomatic (3%)

Fundus Examination
  • White, elevated mass in the retina
  • Can be endophytic, exophytic, or mixed growth

Imaging
  • CT scan: Calcification in 90% of cases
  • MRI: Better for evaluating optic nerve and extraocular extension
  • Ultrasound: Useful for initial screening

Genetic Testing
  • RB1 gene mutation on chromosome 13q14

questions.text: Which of the listed conditions is associated with the presence of punched-out lesions on the retina?

What is the likely cause of sudden loss of vision in the left eye for the past two hours in a 58-year-old man who experienced it after his retirement party? The fundoscopic examination reveals a similar image shown below.
questions.explanation:
Risk Factors
  • Atherosclerosis
  • Age
  • Hypertension/Cardiac Diseases
  • Thrombophilic Disorders
  • Smoking
  • Diabetes Mellitus
  • Oral Contraceptive Pills

Clinical Features

Symptoms:

  • Sudden, painless, profound vision loss.
  • Painful only in GCA: May present with headache, jaw claudication, scalp tenderness, and/or pain around the temple.

 

Clinical Signs:

  • Severely reduced Visual Acuity (VA), often to counting fingers or worse.
  • Profound and sometimes total Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect (RAPD), also called an amaurotic pupil.

Examination Findings

Fundus Examination:

  • Retinal Whitening: Pale and opaque retina, particularly in the posterior pole.
  • Cherry-Red Spot: Bright red area at the fovea due to the contrast between pale retina and underlying choroidal circulation.
  • Cattle Truck Appearance: Segmentation of the blood column in retinal veins.
  • Attenuated Arteries: Narrowed and segmented retinal arterioles.
  • Optic Disc Changes: Pale optic disc over time due to optic atrophy from prolonged ischemia (chronic cases).

Investigations

Fluorescein Angiography (FFA):

  • Delayed arterial filling.
  • Masking of background fluorescence due to edematous retina.
  • Patent Cilioretinal Artery: Area of normal perfusion of a cilioretinal artery supplies the fovea, potentially preserving central vision.

Other Diagnostic Tests:

  • Retinal edema, structural changes, and possibly an embolic plaque within the retinal artery.
  • Cranial MRI or CT.
  • Carotid duplex scanning.
  • Echocardiography.

Management
  • Smoking cessation
  • Ocular massage
  • IOP control agents: Acetazolamide
  • Hyperosmotics: Mannitol
  • Carbogen (95% O2 + 5% CO2) inhalation
  • Nd-YAG laser embolectomy

questions.text: A male patient, aged 18, seeks medical attention due to an eye injury sustained while climbing a tree five days ago. The patient reports experiencing pain, sensitivity to light (photophobia), and redness in the affected eye for the past two days. Upon performing a slit-lamp examination, a lesion is observed as depicted below. Which of the following characteristics is associated with this particular condition?
questions.explanation:
Etiology
  • Causative organism: Aspergillus fumigatus >> Fusarium
  • Predisposing factor: Vegetative matter injury (trauma)

Clinical Features
  • SIGNS >> symptoms
  • Pain & Foreign Body Sensation
  • Watering/ Photophobia
  • Blurred Vision, Redness

Examination Findings
  • Corneal Ulcer: Greyish-white, dry, elevated, rolled-out margins
  • Pigmented Ulcer: Brownish, dematiaceous fungi
  • Feathery Extensions: Finger-like projections in stroma
  • Sterile Immune Ring: Yellow line of demarcation
  • Satellite Lesions (Option D): Small lesions around the main ulcer
  • Hypopyon: Large, immobile, non-sterile, even in small ulcer

Investigations
  • Corneal Scraping: For microbiological examination
  • Wet KOH Mount: Filamentous fungi or yeast-like fungi (Candida)
  • Culture: Sabouraud's agar for fungal culture
  • PCR: For rapid identification of pathogens
  • Corneal Biopsy: For deep stromal abscess or negative cultures

Treatment
  • Topical Antifungal Agents: Natamycin 5%, Voriconazole, Amphotericin-B, Nystatin
  • Oral Antifungal Agents: Ketoconazole, Voriconazole (for severe ulcers)
  • Surgical Management:
    • Repeated Scraping: Removal of necrotic material
    • Cauterization Options: Carbolic acid (100%), Trichloroacetic acid (10%–20%), Povidone-iodine (5%)
    • Therapeutic Keratoplasty: Corneal transplantation

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a 7-year-old boy who showed a white pupillary reflex and underwent enucleation, with histopathological examination showing Flexner Wintersteiner rosettes?
questions.explanation:
Clinical Presentation
  • Leukocoria (60%)
  • Strabismus (20%)
  • Painful red eye (7%)
  • Poor vision (5%)
  • Asymptomatic (3%)

Fundus Examination
  • White, elevated mass in the retina
  • Can be endophytic, exophytic, or mixed growth

Imaging
  • CT scan: Calcification in 90% of cases
  • MRI: Better for evaluating optic nerve and extraocular extension
  • Ultrasound: Useful for initial screening

Histopathology
  • Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes (highly specific): These are composed of an ‘empty’ lumen surrounded by columnar cells
  • Homer-Wright rosettes: These are pseudo-rosettes and consist of cells surrounding a central lumen made up of their processes
  • Undifferentiated tumor cells
  • Areas of necrosis and calcification

Genetic Testing
  • RB1 gene mutation on chromosome 13q14

questions.text: What is the condition characterized by painless vision loss?
questions.explanation:
Risk Factors

Age > 50 years (primary risk factor), Hypertension, Diabetes Mellitus, Hyperlipidemia, Glaucoma (increased IOP), Smoking, Hypercoagulable states

Pathogenesis

Thrombosis driven by venous stasis, endothelial damage, and hypercoagulability

Types

Non-ischemic CRVO (Venous stasis retinopathy) (75% of cases)

  • Mild to moderate, unilateral blurring of vision
  • Fundus: Mild venous congestion and tortuosity, flame-shaped hemorrhages, mild macular edema

 

Ischemic CRVO (Hemorrhagic retinopathy)

  • Severe, sudden visual loss, massive venous engorgement, "splashed-tomato" hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, macular edema
  • Marked vein sheathing, collaterals, neovascularization, chronic cystoid edema

Investigations
  • Ocular Exam: Visual acuity, IOP, Slit-lamp exam (NVI), Gonioscopy (NVA)
  • Goldmann Perimetry and ERG: Differentiating ischemic vs non-ischemic CRVO
  • Fundus Fluorescein Angiography (FFA): Assess retinal perfusion
  • Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT): Assess macular edema, sub-retinal fluid

Treatment
  • Systemic Management: Control of systemic conditions (hypertension, diabetes, hyperlipidemia, hyperhomocysteinemia)
  • Medical Treatment: Intravitreal anti-VEGF (e.g., Bevacizumab), intravitreal steroids (Triamcinolone, Dexamethasone implant)
  • Laser Therapy: Panretinal photocoagulation (PRP) for neovascularization
  • Surgical: Pars plana vitrectomy for complications

Complications

Neovascular glaucoma, Neovascularization of the iris (NVI), Vitreous hemorrhage, Proliferative retinopathy, Chronic macular edema

questions.text: Which of the following parts of the retina are correctly marked?

options.label: A
options.text: 1-Retinal pigment epithelium; 2-Outer nuclear layer; 3-Inner plexiform layer; 4-Ganglion layer B) 1-Retinal pigment epithelium; 2-Inner nuclear layer; 3-Outer plexiform layer; 4-Ganglion layer C) 1-Ganglion layer; 2-Inner nuclear layer; 3-Outer plexiform layer; 4-RPE D) 1-Ganglion layer; 2-Outer plexiform layer; 3-Inner nuclear layer; 4-RPE

options.label: B
options.text: 1-Retinal pigment epithelium; 2-Inner nuclear layer; 3-Outer plexiform layer; 4-Ganglion layer

questions.correct_answer: A. 1-Retinal pigment epithelium; 2-Outer nuclear layer; 3-Inner plexiform layer; 4-Ganglion layer B) 1-Retinal pigment epithelium; 2-Inner nuclear layer; 3-Outer plexiform layer; 4-Ganglion layer C) 1-Ganglion layer; 2-Inner nuclear layer; 3-Outer plexiform layer; 4-RPE D) 1-Ganglion layer; 2-Outer plexiform layer; 3-Inner nuclear layer; 4-RPE
questions.explanation:
Layer

Description

1. Pigment Epithelium

Outermost layer with a single pigmented cell layer; adheres to Bruch's membrane; supports neurosensory retina, and reduces reflection.

Subretinal Space: This is the layer between the Pigment epithelium and the layer of Photoreceptors.

2. Rods and Cones Layer

Contains the outer segments of photoreceptors (rods and cones, which are the first-order neurons); rods detect low-light vision, cones manage color and detailed vision.

3. External Limiting Membrane

A porous membrane allows processes from rods and cones to pass through.

4. Outer Nuclear Layer
(Henle’s layer)

Contains the nuclei of the photoreceptor cells (rods and cones).

5. Outer Plexiform Layer

Includes connections between rods, cones, bipolar cell dendrites, and horizontal cells.

6. Inner Nuclear Layer

Made up of the cell bodies of bipolar cells (which are the second-order neurons), horizontal cells, amacrine cells, and Müller cells; and also contains retinal capillaries.

7. Inner Plexiform Layer

Houses synaptic connections between bipolar cell axons, ganglion cell dendrites, and amacrine cell processes.

8. Ganglion Cell Layer

Contains ganglion cell bodies, which serve as third-order neurons; midget cells synapse with a single bipolar cell, and polysynaptic cells synapse with multiple.

9. Nerve Fiber Layer

Composed of ganglion cell axons that form the optic nerve after passing through the lamina cribrosa.

10. Internal Limiting Membrane

The innermost layer separating the retina from the vitreous; is formed by the terminal expansions of Müller cells, serving as a basement membrane.

questions.text: What is the primary mode of dissemination of retinoblastoma?
questions.explanation:
ICRB Stage

Features

Treatment

A
  • Small intraretinal tumors (<3mm)
  • Located >3 mm from the foveola and >1.5 mm from the optic disc

 
  • Laser photocoagulation: Posterior to equator
  • Cryotherapy: Anterior to equator
  • Thermotherapy
  • Chemoreduction (Etoposide, Vincristine and Carboplatin)

B
  • Large tumors >3 mm in dimension
  • Any size tumors located <3 mm from fovea, and <1.5 mm from the optic disc margin
  • Chemoreduction + focal consolidation
  • Plaque radiotherapy

C
  • Subretinal seeds ≤ 3 mm from tumor
  • Vitreous seeds ≤ 3 mm from tumor
  • Both subretinal and vitreous seeds ≤ 3 mm from tumor
  • Chemoreduction + focal consolidation
  • Possible intravitreal chemotherapy for vitreous seeding

D
  • Subretinal seeds > 3 mm from tumor
  • Vitreous seeds > 3 mm from tumor
  • Both subretinal and vitreous seeds > 3 mm from retinoblastoma
  • Chemoreduction + possible intravitreal chemotherapy
  • External beam radiotherapy in some cases
  • Enucleation if poor response to other treatments

E

Extensive retinoblastoma occupying > 50% of the globe with or without:

  • Neovascular glaucoma
  • Hemorrhage
  • Extension of tumor to optic nerve or anterior chamber
  • Enucleation
  • Possible adjuvant chemotherapy if high-risk features

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 7-year-old patient who presented with a white pupillary reflex and underwent enucleation, with histopathological examination revealing the presence of Flexner Wintersteiner rosettes?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Retinoblastoma

Clinical Presentation
  • Leukocoria (60%)
  • Strabismus (20%)
  • Painful red eye (7%)
  • Poor vision (5%)
  • Asymptomatic (3%)

Fundus Examination
  • White, elevated mass in the retina
  • Can be endophytic, exophytic, or mixed growth

Imaging
  • CT scan: Calcification in 90% of cases
  • MRI: Better for evaluating optic nerve and extraocular extension
  • Ultrasound: Useful for initial screening

Histopathology
  • Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes (highly specific): These are composed of an ‘empty’ lumen surrounded by columnar cells
  • Homer-Wright rosettes: These are pseudo-rosettes and consist of cells surrounding a central lumen made up of their processes
  • Undifferentiated tumor cells
  • Areas of necrosis and calcification

Genetic Testing
  • RB1 gene mutation on chromosome 13q14

questions.text: Shifting fluid sign is seen in?
questions.explanation:
Type of Retinal Detachment

Clinical Features

Rhegmatogenous Retinal Detachment (Option C)

1. Floaters (dark spots) due to rapid vitreous degeneration.

2. Photopsia (flashes of light) caused by retinal irritation from vitreous movements.

3. Gradual visual field loss, initially localized, progressing to total vision loss as detachment spreads.

4. Dark veil/cloud in front of the eye, particularly when detachment reaches the posterior region.

5. Sudden, painless vision loss in large, central detachment.

6. Retinal breaks may be round, horseshoe-shaped, slit-like, or large anterior dialysis.

7. Vitreous pigments (tobacco dusting or Shaffer sign) are seen in the anterior vitreous with posterior vitreous detachment.

8. Old retinal detachment shows retinal thinning, subretinal demarcation lines (high water marks), and secondary intraretinal cysts.

Tractional Retinal Detachment (Option B)

1. Gradual, progressive visual loss

2. Typically painless

3. No associated flashes or floaters

4. Vitreoretinal bands present

5. No retinal breaks

6. Detached area - concave and localized

7. No shifting fluid

Exudative Retinal Detachment (Option A)

1. Painless and sudden or gradual visual loss

2. No photopsia, holes/ tears, folds and undulations.

3. Smooth and convex with pigmentary disturbances

4. Rounded and fixed with neovascularization on the tumor summit.

5. Shifting fluid - changing the position of the detached area with gravity - hallmark feature.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 3-year-old boy who has displayed growing clumsiness over the last half a year, has leukocoria, and lacks red reflex in his left eye? After diagnosis, enucleation was performed, and the specimen displayed Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes under microscopic examination?
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - R

questions.text: What is the condition in which the cherry red spot, as shown in the image below, is observed?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO)

questions.text: In which diseases are microaneurysms observed?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Diabetic retinopathy

Early NPDR or Background Diabetic Retinopathy

Severe NPDR or Preproliferative Diabetic Retinopathy
  • Affects small retinal vessels.
  • Earliest sign: Microaneurysm (Option B)
    • Fluorescein angiography (FA): Tiny hyperfluorescent dots.
  • Retinal hemorrhages: Both deep, i.e., in the inner nuclear or outer plexiform layer (dot and blot hemorrhage) and superficial, i.e., in nerve fiber layer (splinter or flame-shaped) hemorrhages
  • Hard exudates:
    • White or yellow waxy patches with well-defined margins, often at the posterior pole, in the outer plexiform layer.
    • FA: Hypofluorescence with dense exudates.
  • Edema is not marked.
  • Increased inner retinal hypoxia: Leads to multiple retinal hemorrhages, cotton-wool spots, venous beading, vascular loops, intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMAs), and large areas of capillary nonperfusion.
  • Cotton-Wool Spots:
    • Also called soft exudates or nerve fiber infarcts.
    • Result from ischemia, not exudation.
    • Caused by obstruction of axoplasmic flow, leading to swelling and a white, fluffy appearance.
    • FA: Focal hypofluorescence due to local ischemia.
  • Venous Beading:
    • Indicates sluggish retinal circulation.
    • Typically adjacent to large areas of capillary nonperfusion.
  • Intraretinal Microvascular Abnormalities (IRMA):
    • Dilated capillaries act as collateral channels.
    • Bypass capillary bed and is often seen adjacent to capillary nonperfusion.
    • FA: Focal hypofluorescence

questions.text: All of the following are causes for expanding blind spots, except for...

A patient with a history of diabetes and hypertension underwent fundus fluorescent angiography (FFA) to evaluate his decreasing vision. The FFA yields an image as shown below, which is characteristic of :
questions.explanation:
Correct option A

Condition

Description

Macular Ischemia

Inadequate blood supply to the macula

Enlarged foveal avascular zone

Reduced blood flow and oxygen delivery to the macula

Macular Edema

Can cause vision loss and impairment of central vision

Accumulation of fluid in the macula

Swelling and distortion of central vision

Can be caused by various conditions, including diabetes

Submacular Hemorrhage

 

Can lead to vision loss and blurred vision

Bleeding underneath the macula

Sudden and severe vision loss

Can be caused by various conditions, such as AMD

Premacular Hemorrhage

Requires immediate medical attention

Bleeding within the macula itself

Acute vision loss

Can be caused by trauma or retinal vascular disorders

Requires ophthalmological evaluation and management

questions.text: A 55-year-old hypertensive patient presented with complaints of blurred vision and headaches. On retinal examination, the following findings were observed: multiple flame-shaped hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, and disc edema. Based on the Keith-Wagner classification, which grade of hypertensive retinopathy is this patient most likely classified as?
questions.explanation:
Grade Fundus Findings Clinical Features
Grade 1 Mild arteriolar narrowing Usually asymptomatic
Grade 2 Moderate arteriolar narrowing + AV nicking Often asymptomatic or mild symptoms
Grade 3 Grade 2 + Flame-shaped hemorrhages + Cotton wool spots + hard exudates Visual symptoms possible
Grade 4 Grade 3 + Papilledema (disc edema) Malignant hypertension symptoms like headache, blurred vision

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about Retinitis Pigmentosa?

options.label: A
options.text: ERG shows decreased amplitude of a and b waves B) Rod dystrophy > Cone dystrophy C) Late presentation is loss of peripheral vision D) Night vision is lost late and rare

options.label: C
options.text: Late presentation is loss of peripheral vision

options.label: D
options.text: Night vision is lost late and rare

questions.correct_answer: D. Night vision is lost late and rare

questions.text: Which of the following is a complication of diabetic retinopathy?
Which of the following is the diagnostic investigation for Best disease?

options.label: A
options.text: EOG B) ERG C) Multifocal ERG D) Visual evoked potential

questions.correct_answer: A. EOG B) ERG C) Multifocal ERG D) Visual evoked potential

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby, born preterm at 33 weeks of gestation, is brought by parents with complaints of a white pupillary reflex for 2 weeks. CT revealed calcification of the globe in both eyes. What is the probable diagnosis?

  • Chemoreduction + focal consolidation
  • Plaque radiotherapy

C
  • Subretinal seeds ≤ 3 mm from tumor
  • Vitreous seeds ≤ 3 mm from tumor
  • Both subretinal and vitreous seeds ≤ 3 mm from tumor
  • Chemoreduction + focal consolidation
  • Possible intravitreal chemotherapy for vitreous seeding

D
  • Subretinal seeds > 3 mm from tumor
  • Vitreous seeds > 3 mm from tumor
  • Both subretinal and vitreous seeds > 3 mm from retinoblastoma
  • Chemoreduction + possible intravitreal chemotherapy
  • External beam radiotherapy in some cases
  • Enucleation, if poor response to other treatments

E

Extensive retinoblastoma occupying > 50% of the globe with or without:

  • Neovascular glaucoma
  • Hemorrhage
  • Extension of tumor to optic nerve or anterior chamber
  • Enucleation
  • Possible adjuvant chemotherapy if high-risk features

questions.text: A patient presents with vision problems and has a history of cataract surgery. OCT finding is shown below. What is the syndrome most likely associated with these findings?
A patient presents with a gradual loss of night vision and peripheral vision. What is the most likely diagnosis based on fundoscopy findings?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Retinitis pig

questions.text: A child presents with leukocoria and an intraocular mass. Microscopic examination reveals rosettes with scanty cytoplasm, and the mass is positive for synaptophysin and chromogranin. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A – R

questions.text: Which of the following criteria is not included in the definition of severe Non-Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (NPDR)?
questions.explanation:
Category

Management

Non-Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (NPDR):

No Diabetic Retinopathy

Review in 12 months

Very Mild NPDR

Microaneurysms only

Review most patients in 12 months

 

Mild NPDR

Any or all of the: microaneurysms, retinal hemorrhages, exudates, and cotton-wool spots, up to the level of moderate NPDR. No intraretinal microvascular anomalies (IRMA) or significant beading.

Review range 6-12 months, depending on the severity of signs, stability, systemic factors, and patient's circumstances

Moderate NPDR

  • Severe retinal hemorrhages in 1-3 quadrants or mild IRMA
  • Significant venous beading can be present in no more than 1 quadrant
  • Cotton wool spots commonly present

Review in approximately 6 months

 

Severe NPDR

The 4-2-1 rule; is one or more of the:

  • Severe hemorrhages in all 4 quadrants (Option B ruled out)
  • Significant venous beading in 2 or more quadrants (Option D ruled out)
  • Moderate IRMA in 1 or more quadrants (Option A ruled out)

Review in 4 months

Very severe NPDR

Two or more of the criteria for severe NPDR

Review in 2-3 months

questions.text: A 72-year-old patient, with a history of cataract surgery and diabetes mellitus, presents with decreased vision one month after surgery. Examination reveals a honeycomb appearance or flower petal pattern of the retina. What is the likely diagnosis?
A patient with rheumatoid arthritis who is noncompliant with treatment presents with complaints of superior field loss of vision for the past week. What is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Type Subtypes Main Cause Key Clinical Feature
Arterial Central Retinal Artery Occlusion (CRAO) Embolism (carotid or cardiac) Sudden, complete monocular blindness
  Branch Retinal Artery Occlusion (BRAO) Embolism to a branch retinal artery Sudden, sectoral visual field loss
Venous Central Retinal Vein Occlusion (CRVO) Hypertension, glaucoma, hyperviscosity Gradual or sudden blurring, "blood and thunder" fundus
  Branch Retinal Vein Occlusion (BRVO) Hypertension, arteriosclerosis Sectoral hemorrhages, partial visual blurring
Occlusion Type Pathogenesis
Artery Embolic or thrombotic occlusion → retinal ischemia → inner retinal layer damage
Vein Venous stasis + increased backpressure → hemorrhage, macular edema, ischemia
Condition Fundus Appearance
CRAO Pale retina, cherry-red spot at macula
BRAO Localized pale retina corresponding to affected artery
CRVO Diffuse retinal hemorrhages, dilated tortuous veins, optic disc edema
BRVO Hemorrhages limited to one quadrant or sector of retina
Systemic Ocular
Hypertension Glaucoma
Diabetes mellitus Optic disc crowding
Atherosclerosis Increased IOP
Rheumatic heart disease Retinal vascular anomalies
Hypercoagulable states —
Condition Visual Field
CRAO Total field loss
BRAO Quadrantic or sectoral loss (e.g., superior field loss = inferior retinal BRAO)
CRVO Diffuse loss or central blurring
BRVO Sectoral field defect

Condition Management
CRAO Ocular massage, reduce IOP, hyperbaric O2, treat cause (e.g., embolus)
BRAO Often irreversible; investigate embolic source (heart, carotid)
CRVO/BRVO Control risk factors, anti-VEGF injections, grid laser (for macular edema), PRP (for neovascularization)

questions.text: A 22-year-old patient with high myopia and thick glasses presents with floaters in his eyes. What is the likely cause of this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - Retinal detach

questions.text: What could be the cause of sudden painless loss of vision?
Which of the following conditions is associated with the curtain falling sign?
questions.explanation:
Type of Retinal Detachment

Clinical Features

Rhegmatogenous Retinal Detachment
  • Floaters (dark spots) due to rapid vitreous degeneration.
  • Photopsia (flashes of light) caused by retinal irritation from vitreous movements.
  • Gradual visual field loss, initially localized, progressing to total vision loss as detachment spreads.
  • Dark veil/Curtain falling sign/cloud in front of the eye, particularly when detachment reaches the posterior region.
  • Sudden, painless vision loss in large, central detachment.
  • Retinal breaks may be round, horseshoe-shaped, slit-like, or large anterior dialysis.
  • Vitreous pigments (tobacco dusting or Shaffer sign) are seen in the anterior vitreous with posterior vitreous detachment.
  • Old retinal detachment shows retinal thinning, subretinal demarcation lines (high water marks), and secondary intraretinal cysts.

Tractional Retinal Detachment
  • Gradual, progressive visual loss
  • Typically painless
  • No associated flashes or floaters
  • Vitreoretinal bands present
  • No retinal breaks
  • Detached area - concave and localized
  • No shifting fluid

Exudative Retinal Detachment
  • Painless and sudden or gradual visual loss
  • No photopsia, holes/ tears, folds and undulations.
  • Smooth and convex with pigmentary disturbances
  • Rounded and fixed with neovascularization on the tumor summit.
  • Shifting fluid - changing the position of the detached area with gravity - hallmark feature.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about Retinitis pigmentosa?

options.label: A
options.text: ERG show decreased amplitude of a and b wave

options.label: C
options.text: Late presentation is loss of peripheral vision

options.label: D
options.text: Night vision is lost late and rare

questions.correct_answer: D. Night vision is lost late and rare
questions.explanation: Correct Option D - Night vision

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of visual disturbances. He reports that he is unable to see on the left side from the left eye and the left side from his right eye. However, he notices that his central vision remains intact and unaffected. The patient denies any recent trauma or other significant medical history. What is the most likely visual deficit that the patient is experiencing?
questions.correct_answer: D. Homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing
questions.explanation: Correct Option D - Homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presents to the clinic with a complaint of sudden visual blurring that lasted for a short duration . He reports that during the episode, he completely lost vision in his left eye for a few minutes and then regained his vision . The patient denies any pain, headache, or other associated symptoms during the episode. What is the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Amaurosis Fug

questions.text: Identify the marked layer of the retina
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Inner plexiform

questions.text: Identify the lesion in the histopathological image of retina.
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Dru

questions.text: What could be the likely diagnosis for a 65-year-old female patient with a prior diagnosis of chronic arthritis, undergoing treatment, who presents with complaints of impaired vision in both eyes and fundus angiography depicted the following finding?
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - Chloroquine

questions.text: The image is suggestive of?
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - Cystoid macular

questions.text: At what point would you suggest conducting a dilated fundus examination for a person diagnosed with diabetes on their 45 th birthday?

options.label: D
options.text: When the complains of decrease in vision

questions.explanation: Correct Option A - I

questions.text: To confirm the diagnosis, what additional investigation should be conducted for a child exhibiting symptoms of night blindness and delayed dark adaptation?
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - ERG

questions.text: What is true regarding retinoscopy using a plane mirror?

options.label: A
options.text: In hypermetropia the red glow moves in opposite direction

options.label: B
options.text: In myopia the red glow moves in same direction

options.label: C
options.text: In emmetropia the red glow moves in opposite direction

options.label: D
options.text: Done at 1 meter away from patient

questions.correct_answer: D. Done at 1 meter away from patient
questions.explanation: Correct Option D - D

questions.text: Roth spots are seen in ____________.
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Acute leuk

questions.text: What is the commonly used chemotherapy regimen for the treatment of retinoblastoma?
questions.explanation: Correct Option D - Vincristine, carboplatin,

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about retinitis pigmentosa?
questions.explanation: Correct Option D - ERG

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with retinitis pigmentosa?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Arteriolar attenu

questions.text: What would be the diagnosis for a diabetic patient experiencing an abrupt vision loss, having a visual acuity of 6/60, with a fundus picture provided?
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - CRAO:

questions.text: Please identify the structure indicated by the arrow.
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - Ch

questions.text: ETDRS study was related to
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - Diabetic macular

questions.text: A 61-year-old university professor complains of vision loss in his left eye. He compares the sensation to a curtain being pulled over his affected eye. Additionally, he experienced flashing lights and floaters a week ago. The provided image shows a B-scan of his left eye. What could be the possible diagnosis for his condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - Retinal detach

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 3-year-old boy who has been displaying increased clumsiness for the past 6 months, and upon examination, a cauliflower-like growth, leukocoria, and an absent red reflex in the left eye? Enucleation was performed, and microscopic examination of the specimen reveals the presence of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes.
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - R
